title: Is someone with an associates degree considered a college graduate, if it came from an accredited university? - Quora

response.answer_text: Universities don’t award associates degrees. An associate’s degree is a two-year degree awarded by community colleges. I’ve never heard of a four year school awarding associates degrees. Now, to answer your question, yes, if you have an associate’s degree, you ARE a college graduate. If you are asked on a job application or during an interview, you can say that you are a college graduate because it is true; you are a college graduate, but you should go further and explain that you have an associate’s from, for example, Bunker Hill Community College. Some people equate the term “college graduate” with people who have bachelors’ degrees, so if you say you are a college graduate, they may assume you have a bachelor’s degree, and if you don’t disabuse them of this idea, then you could later be fired for lying by omission (by not telling them that your degree is an associate’s degree).

The term “College Graduate” is kind of generic for graduating from college. If you graduate from a 2 year college, you are a college graduate, because you graduated from a college. I have noticed that the jobs that advertise required education, especially in the federal government, do not state the requirement as a “College Graduate.” The requirement is stated as something like, “A course of study, leading to a 4 year college degree” or words to that effect. If it is a job that requires a 2 year degree, “2” would be substituted for “4.” That eliminates the ambiguity of just stating that a college degree is required. By the way, furthering your education is commendable, whether it be an associate’s degree, bachelor’s degree, master’s degree or PhD.
